s.text: SYSTAT version 8.0 for Windows of the SPSS Inc. (Chicago, Illinois, USA) was used for statistical analysis.
As a higher insulin level is a surrogate for decreased insulin sensitivity, their observation suggests that a higher vitamin D level is associated with increased insulin sensitivity.
BMD is known to have strong genetic determinants.

From the Rancho Bernardo Study [ 5], the level of fasting insulin was significantly and positively associated with BMD in non-diabetic female subjects, where each 10 ?U/ml increase in fasting insulin level was associated with an increase of BMD by 0.33 g/cm 2in the radius and 0.57 g/cm 2in the spine.
Since a variation in serum osteocalcin level was shown to have a strong genetic component mediated through the VDR, the relationship between VDR polymorphisms and serum osteocalcin level was found.
As a higher insulin level is a surrogate for decreased insulin sensitivity, their observation suggests that a higher vitamin D level is associated with increased insulin sensitivity.

Although the speculated mechanism of our observation is in agreement with the published association between vitamin D levels and insulin sensitivity, further studies are required to confirm our observation in other ethnic groups as well as in another Caucasian population.
Glucose tolerance and vitamin D level were assessed in 142 elderly Dutchmen.
The insulin sensitivity and beta cell function were estimated using a homeostasis model assessment (HOMA) [ 15].
To examine the influence of the available covariates in addition to the Fok I polymorphism on beta cell function and insulin sensitivity, we employed a stepwise regression analytical approach.
